DCL OS Abstraction Symbols

Send comments on this topic.
These preprocessor symbols are used to implement the operating system abstraction. Typically they define OS characteristics or behaviors so that the OS abstraction code can operate properly, resulting in a uniform OS abstraction presented to the other layers of software.

These preprocessor symbols are typically constant for the OS, and have global scope. However, for some OS abstractions, some of these symbols may be superseded at the project level.

Summary

DCL_ALIGNSIZE   Define data alignment boundaries as required by the operating system and enforced by the compiler.
DCL_CPU_ALIGNSIZE   Define the CPU specific alignment requirements.
DCL_IOCTL_BLOCKDEV   The OS specific IOCTL number used to send requests to a block device.
DCL_IOCTL_FILESYS   The OS specific IOCTL number used to send requests to a file system.
DCL_IOCTL_MAX_REQUESTS   Specifies the maximum number of devices which may be opened via the external requestor interface.
DCL_OSFEATURE_CONSOLEINPUT   A TRUE or FALSE value which defines whether the OS abstraction supports console-input.
DCL_OSFEATURE_THREADS   A TRUE or FALSE value which defines whether the OS supports threads or not.
DCL_OSFEATURE_UNICODE   A TRUE or FALSE value which defines whether the OS supports Unicode or not.
DCL_OSNAME   Defines the name of the OS abstraction, and may be mixed case.
DCL_PATHSEPCHAR   The default character used as a path separator.
DCL_PATHSEPSTR   The default character used as a path separator, in string form.

DCL_ALIGNSIZE

Define data alignment boundaries as required by the operating system and enforced by the compiler. This value is used by Datalight software as the minimum boundary on which declared structures and allocated memory must be aligned.

DCL_ALIGNSIZE may not be greater than the alignment enforced by the compiler when allotting space for the maximum size native type (D_UINT32 or D_UINT64). There is no practical reason for this value to ever be less than 4 since all the modern compilers Datalight currently deals with ensure that 32-bit values are always aligned, even when using processor such as x86 which does not require it.

DCL_ALIGNSIZE is always the exact with of the DCL_ALIGNTYPE data type, and is always as large or larger than DCL_CPU_ALIGNSIZE.

DCL_CPU_ALIGNSIZE

Define the CPU specific alignment requirements. Most processors used in the embedded environment have strict data alignment requirements, and the compilers used therein ensure this alignment. However some processors, notably the x86 do not require alignment, even though it is desirable for performance reasons.

This setting is normally only used by code which is doing memory-mapped I/O.

DCL_IOCTL_BLOCKDEV

The OS specific IOCTL number used to send requests to a block device. The default value for this setting is specified in the OS-specific dlosconf.h file, but may be superseded at the project level by defining it in dclconf.h.

DCL_IOCTL_FILESYS

The OS specific IOCTL number used to send requests to a file system. The default value for this setting is specified in the OS-specific dlosconf.h file, but may be superseded at the project level by defining it in dclconf.h.

DCL_IOCTL_MAX_REQUESTS

Specifies the maximum number of devices which may be opened via the external requestor interface. This is typically set to zero in environments which do not support a requestor interface. The default value for this setting is specified in the OS-specific dlosconf.h file, but may be superseded at the project level by defining it in dclconf.h.

DCL_OSFEATURE_CONSOLEINPUT

A TRUE or FALSE value which defines whether the OS abstraction supports console-input.

DCL_OSFEATURE_THREADS

A TRUE or FALSE value which defines whether the OS supports threads or not.

DCL_OSFEATURE_UNICODE

A TRUE or FALSE value which defines whether the OS supports Unicode or not. If this symbol is TRUE, then the data type D_WCHAR must be defined.

DCL_OSNAME

Defines the name of the OS abstraction, and may be mixed case.

DCL_PATHSEPCHAR

The default character used as a path separator. This does not imply that other path separator characters are not legal, just that this will be the default character used.

DCL_PATHSEPSTR

The default character used as a path separator, in string form. This does not imply that other path separator characters are not legal, just that this will be the default character used.
